questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a palpable lump in her left breast which is freely mobile and painless. A biopsy of the lump was performed, and a histopathological examination was done. Which feature from the biopsy report is most likely to differentiate between benign and malignant breast lesions?

choices.text: Evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Evidence of invasion into surrounding tissues

 

Explanation:

  • We differentiate benign and malignant tumours based on whether the basement membrane is intact or broken:
    • In benign tumours: The basement membrane is completely intact and normal.
    • In malignant tumours: The basement membrane is broken, so the cancer cells can invade surrounding tissues.

 

Feature

Benign Lesions

Malignant Lesions

Growth

Localised

Invasive (Option B)

Microscopic Appearance

Resemble normal tissue and maintain differentiated features. (Option A)

Cellular atypia, mitotic figures, loss of tissue organisation.

Macroscopic Appearance

Well-defined borders

Irregular borders, necrosis, hemorrhage.

Histological Features

Cells are typically uniform in size and shape, with minimal nuclear atypia and low mitotic rate. (Option C)

Cells may display pleomorphism, increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, high mitotic rate, and evidence of invasion or metastasis.

questions.text: Which of the following tumour is of mesenchymal origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Leiomyoma

 

Explanation:

Leiomyoma is a benign tumour of mesenchymal origin, originating from the smooth muscles of the uterus.

Adenoma (Option A): Arises from gland: Epithelial Tumour

Papilloma (Option B): Usually arises from surfaces like skin: Epithelial Tumour

Seminoma (Option C): Germ cell tumour in testes: Epithelial Tumour

 

 

Mesenchymal Tumours

Epithelial Tumours

Origin
  • Connective tissues and derivatives
  • Blood and lymph vessels
  • Hematopoietic stem cells and lymphoid tissue
  • Meninges
  • Mesothelium
  • Smooth muscles and Skeletal muscles
  • Stratified squamous epithelium
  • Melanocytes and basal cells of the skin
  • Glandular epithelium and epithelium of ducts
  • Respiratory, Hepatic, Renal, Transitional, Testicular, Placental epithelium

Examples
  • Leiomyosarcoma
  • Lipoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Fibrosarcoma
  • Meningioma
  • Synovial sarcoma
  • Adenocarcinoma
  • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Adenoma
  • Papilloma
  • Seminoma
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Transitional cell carcinoma

Markers
  • Vimentin
  • Desmin
  • S100 Protein
  • Fibronectin
  • Myogenin
  • Cytokeratin
  • Epithelial Membrane Antigen (EMA)
  • E-Cadherin
  • P63, P40
  • Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of a patient with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the right parotid gland region that is well-defined and heterogeneous, with both epithelial and mesenchymal components present in the biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pleomorphic adenoma
 

Explanation:

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumour of the salivary glands, often found in the parotid gland.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma, also known as a mixed tumour, typically contains epithelial components (such as glandular cells) and mesenchymal components (such as myxoid stroma, islands of cartilage, or bone).
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is more commonly found in females.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with pelvic pain and irregular menstrual cycles. She undergoes surgical resection of the mass, and histopathological examination reveals a tumour composed of mature tissues derived from multiple germ layers, including hair, teeth, and sebaceous material. Based on the histopathological findings described, which of the following tumours is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Teratoma

 

Explanation:

  • Teratomas arise from 2 or more germ layers
  • Teratomas are commonly seen in the ovaries, but can also be seen in other organs of the body.
  • Teratomas are of 2 types:
    • Mature teratoma: Benign and has all the mature tissues
    • Immature teratoma: Has neuroepithelial cells and has the potential to cause cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with chronic heartburn and difficulty swallowing. Upon examination, the physician suspects gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and orders an upper GI endoscopic biopsy, which reveals the presence of columnar epithelium in the lower oesophagus, replacing the normal squamous epithelium. Which of the following terms describes the observed cellular change?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metaplasia

 

Explanation:

  • Metaplasia is defined as the replacement of one type of epithelium with another.
  • Metaplasia is 100% reversible.
    • Until the trigger (GERD in this case) is present, metaplasia will stay, and metaplasia will be reversed when the trigger is treated.
  • The terminology of metaplasia is based on the end epithelium it forms.
  • Intestinal columnar epithelium has goblet cells. Acidic mucin is present inside goblet cells, which is Alcian blue positive.
  • Barrett's esophagus is a precancerous condition, and if not treated, it may turn into Adenocarcinoma of esophagus.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not a characteristic of anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intact basement membrane

 

Explanation:

Differentiation between precancer and cancer is based on the basement membrane.

  • If the basement membrane is intact: Precancer/Dysplasia
  • If the basement membrane is broken or breached: Cancer cells can invade into surrounding tissue and spread anywhere:  Cancer/Anaplaisa

 

Image showing Mitosis: Mercedes Benz sign

Image showing Mitosis: Starburst mitosis

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are True?


	The basement membrane remains intact in dysplasia.
	Dysplasia is always irreversible. 
	Pleomorphism is observed in metaplasia.
	Myositis ossificans is an example of dysplasia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 only

 

Explanation:

 

Feature

Metaplasia

Dysplasia

Anaplasia

Definition

Differentiated cell

type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type

Disordered growth and loss of architectural orientation of cells

Lack of cellular differentiation and organisation

Nature (Statement 2)

Adaptive response to stress or injury

Preneoplastic

Associated with malignant transformation

Reversibility

Reversible

Reversible in early stages

(irreversible if whole

the epithelium is involved)

Irreversible

Pleomorphism (Statement 3)

Absent

Present in low-grade

Present in high-grade

Nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio

Normal (1:4 to 1:6)

Increased (↑)

Increased (↑↑↑)

Mitotic figures

Absent/minimal at normal places

Typical mitotic figures present at abnormal places

Atypical, bizarre mitotic figures

present at abnormal places

Basement membrane integrity

Intact

Intact

Breached

Example (Statement 4)

Barret’s oesophagus,

myositis ossificans

Cervical dysplasia of

squamous cells

Carcinoma of the cervix, carcinoma oesophagus

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics distinguishes hemangiomas from other benign tumors?

choices.text: Presence of extracellular matrix (ECM) deposited by stromal cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Unencapsulated

 

Explanation: A hemangioma is a benign vascular tumour caused by an abnormal overgrowth of blood vessels that is distinguished from other benign tumours by:

  • Lack of well-defined capsule (Hemangiomas are uncapsulated).
  • Tendency to permeate the site of origin making it difficult for surgical excision.

 

Rapid growth rate (Option A):

The rapid growth rate is a feature of malignant tumors, not benign tumors which grow slowly and localized to the site of origin.

 

Presence of extracellular matrix (ECM) deposited by stromal cells (Option B):

Benign tumours usually has a capsule, which consists of an extracellular matrix (ECM) deposited by stromal cells such as fibroblasts.

Since hemangioma is unencapsulated, it is not associated with the deposition of extracellular matrix by stromal cells.

 

Easily resected by excision (Option C):

Encapsulation makes benign tumours easily resectable but since hemangiomas are unencapsulated ,they permeate site of origin making it difficult to resect.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cancer is least likely to exhibit distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Basal cell carcinoma


 

Explanation:

Metastasis means the distant spread of cancer.

All cancers are capable of showing metastasis except 2 cancers, which show local invasion:

  1. Basal cell cancer/Rodent's ulcer, which occurs on face.
  2. Gliomas: Brain tumour.

questions.text: Which of the following tumours do not typically exhibit direct seeding of body cavities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Explanation:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma typically exhibits metastasis by hematogenous spread rather than direct seeding of body cavities.

 

Direct Seeding of Body Cavities or Surfaces:

  1. Pseudomyxoma peritonei (Option A) is characterized by the presence of a gelatinous neoplastic mass filling the peritoneal cavity arising from the rupture of mucin-secreting adenocarcinoma of the appendix (most common cause) or mucin-secreting adenocarcinoma of ovarian.
  2. Gastric carcinoma (Option B) can spread to the distal end of the peritoneal cavity (Pouch of Douglas) and is known as the ‘Blummer shelf.’
  3. Medulloblastoma (Option D) from the cerebellum spreads to the spinal cord by ‘Drop metastasis.’

questions.text: Which of the following tumours does not follow the lymphatic metastatic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Follicular thyroid carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Hematogenous spread

Lymphatic spread

Transcoelomic spread

Veins are more prone to invasion than arteries due to their thinner walls.

Tumours use existing lymphatic vessels at their margins. Follows natural routes of lymphatic drainage.

Invades the serosal wall of the coelomic cavity, releasing tumour fragments into coelomic fluid, which is implanted elsewhere in the body cavity.

Seen in most of the sarcomas.

Seen in most carcinomas.

Krukenberg tumour is a metastatic tumour to the ovary that can show lymphatic or transcoelomic spread. (Option B)

Exceptions:

  • Synovial sarcoma (Option D)
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option A)


These tumours are spread by the lymphatic route.

Exceptions:

  • HCC
  • RCC
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid (Option C)


These tumours are spread by a hematogenous route.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Sentinel lymph node?

choices.text: The first lymph node to receive metastasis from a secondary tumour.
Also helpful in identifying metastasis in Melanoma.
The presence of cancer cells indicates a good prognosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Also helpful in identifying metastasis in Melanoma.

 

Explanation:

Sentinel lymph node (SLN): The first lymph node to receive drainage from a primary tumor site.

  • Example: In breast cancer, usually axillary lymph node is the first lymph node where the lymphatics are drained. Hence, it is the sentinel lymph node.

  • Sometimes, cancer may bypass the sentinel lymph node and spread directly to other lymph nodes. This can occur in patients who have received radiotherapy, as radiation can cause fibrosis and blockage of the lymphatic channels. If the pathway to the sentinel node is obstructed, tumour cells are diverted to alternative routes, resulting in what is known as skip metastasis.

  • Tumors where SLN biopsy is validated are Breast cancer, Melanoma, Vulvar cancer, and Colon cancer.

The first lymph node to receive metastasis from a secondary tumour (Option A): Sentinal lymph node is the first lymph node to receive drainage from a primary tumor site.

Commonly involved in skip metastasis (Option C): Skip metastasis is not a very common phenomenon; it's rather rare.

The presence of cancer cells indicates a good prognosis (Option D): Cancer spreading to the sentinel or any other lymph node is always a bad prognosis.
